Graphical abstract The development of coke-resistant catalysts for dry reforming of methane (DRM) is critical for sustainable syngas production. To suppress coking, this study investigates the use of Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx MXenes as support for Ni catalysts in DRM and benchmarked their performance with conventional catalysts (Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, and Ni/SiO2). The MXenes were etched using NH4HF2, and a 10 wt% Ni loading on the supports was achieved via wet impregnation synthesis. Ni/Nb2CTx showed the highest H2 consumption (10.4 mmolH2/gcat). DRM was conducted at 700 °C using a feed ratio of CH4/CO2 of 1:1 and a high space velocity (90,000 ml/gcat h). Unlike the other catalysts, Ni/Nb2CTx pre-reduced at 500 °C exhibited a low normalized coking rate (4.41 µgcoke/mmolCH4), a high overall reaction rate (104 ± 13 mmol/gNi.min), and the highest turnover frequency at 16.7 s−1. The apparent CO2 reaction rate at these conditions was similar to the CH4 rate, suggesting that the low coking rate was due to the efficient utilization of dissociated oxygen. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations performed on NbC(111) and TiC(111) surfaces at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure reveal that the efficient utilization was mediated by rapid oxygen spillover. The average oxygen velocity from the simulations was slightly higher on NbC (0.0969 Å/fs) than on TiC (0.0961 Å/fs). Both MXene supports are transformed to stable oxycarbides during DRM, and Nb2CTx was stable for 50 h TOS. This investigation not only highlights the potential of Ni/Nb2CTx as a coke- and sintering-resistant catalyst but also demonstrates the role of MXenes supports in the DRM process. Keywords Dry reforming MXenes Catalyst design Sintering resistance Supported catalyst Renewable energy Syngas Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction MXenes are a class of 2D layered materials with the general formula of Mn+1XnTx, where M is an early transition metal, X is carbon and/or nitrogen, and Tx is the terminations at the surface of the outer metal layers [1]; ‘n’ stands for the number of layers of the metal present in the MXene and it can be between 1 and 4. In the earliest MXenes synthesized, M was a single type of transition metal. Multiple transition metals can now be incorporated in the same MXene in an ordered or disordered (solid solution) arrangement [2,3]. The MAX phase is the parent layered material from which MXenes are formed. The MXene is obtained when the A element is etched from the MAX phase. MXenes have a wide range of applications in energy [4–7], biomedicine [8–11], electronics [12–14], environmental protection [15–17], sensors [18–20], and catalysis [21–23]. In thermo-catalysis [24], MXenes have been studied for CO2 reduction [25], ethanol reforming [26], reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) [27], hydrogenation [28], dehydrogenation [29], desulfurization [30], and dry reforming [31]. With increasing global energy demand, climate change, and the need for alternative energy sources [32,33], dry reforming of methane (DRM) has gained relevance in recent years. The bulk of global hydrogen production is from steam reforming, which generates carbon dioxide as a by-product [34]. DRM is an endothermic reaction that utilizes CH4 and CO2 (greenhouse gases) for the production of synthesis gas (mixture of H2 and CO) [35]. It is a cleaner and eco-friendly hydrogen production process. The DRM reaction requires a catalyst, usually a transition or noble metal, on a support [36]. Nickel has lower coking resistance than noble metals [37,38] but is more cost-effective [39], making it preferable for large-scale applications [40]. The ensemble size [41,42], nature of the support [41], and utilization of dopants [42] play important roles in Ni coking resistance. The challenge of coking with Ni catalyst is exacerbated due to the relatively low oxygen-carbon (O/C) ratio of the feed. Effective catalysts must be designed to simultaneously minimize the coking of the catalyst and maintain high reaction rates of CO2 and CH4. A low coking resistance can lead to catalyst encapsulation, pore blocking, reactor plugging, and eventual loss of catalytic activity. MXenes have composition and surface terminations along with interlayer spacing that can be tailored to enhance surface basicity, high dispersion of small catalyst particles, and good metal-support interactions (MSI)—features that have been exploited in other studies to improve the coke and sintering resistance of Ni-based catalysts [43–47]. Several studies have evaluated the performance of MXenes as catalyst supports in DRM. Huang et al. [48] used V2CTx as support for Ni and observed stable CH4 and CO2 conversions of 94 % and 89 %, respectively, for 90 h time on stream (TOS). They also observed the partial oxidation of the support to an oxide, which did not limit the performance of the catalyst. A similar investigation performed by Wysocka et al. [49] for V2CTx-supported Ni showed partial MXene oxidation and stable performance for 20 h TOS, which was superior to Ni/SiO2 under similar conditions. Lv et al. [50] calculated the CH4 binding and cohesive energies on Nb2CTx with different surface terminations (O, F, Cl, OH) with potential application in DRM in mind. Their results reveal that CH4 adsorption is weak, and –OH terminations are preferred for methane adsorption. Also, =O terminations are better for the stability of the MXene. Besides their use as support, other studies have shown that the partial oxidation of Mo2CTx [51] and V2CTx [52] can make them active in DRM without requiring an active catalyst via the oxidation-carburization mechanism. A summary of studies utilizing MXene-based catalysts in DRM, along with the experimental conditions and reactant conversion, is presented in Table S1. In a recent review of the literature [31], we observed the lack of investigations on Ti3C2Tx-supported catalysts in dry reforming. Ti3C2Tx is the most widely used MXene in various applications and is relatively cheaper than others. In particular, we highlighted the unique properties of MXenes that can be exploited in heterogeneous thermal catalysis, such as intercalating catalyst nanoparticles in the interlayer space of MXene, thereby taking advantage of the large surface area of the 2D material. Another interesting feature of MXenes is that their partial oxidation does not limit catalytic activity [53]. The oxides formed are also stable in DRM conditions and can preserve reactant flux to the catalyst, as well as improve CO2 adsorption, activation, and dissociation rates. These properties are critical in limiting the coking rate of the catalyst. Besides the conventional MXenes (Ti3C2Tx), we are particularly interested in Nb2CTx because it can be oxidized to an oxycarbide with oxygen vacancies that have low vacancy formation energy [53,54]. Oxygen vacancies in DRM can improve oxygen spillover, leading to efficient coke oxidation. The conductive nature of the support can also improve the oxygen spillover and eventual coke oxidation by stabilizing the O* radicals and facilitating ion exchange, allowing for greater surface migration distances. These exciting features of MXenes have inspired the current investigation. Our previous work on DRM revealed that the coking rate can be lowered using a strongly basic support like CeO2, which facilitates high CO2 chemisorption and activation [55]. The challenge with this approach is that high oxidant concentration exacerbates the thermodynamics effect and favors the RWGS reaction. RWGS in DRM leads to water generation and reduction of H2/CO ratio. A better approach is to use conductive support like MXenes, which favors a more rapid O* spillover. In such cases, oxygen obtained from CO2 dissociation is more effectively used in coke oxidation, and the need for high CO2 rate in coke oxidation is overcome. In this study, we aim to exploit the unique properties of MXenes to design an active Ni-based catalyst with improved stability (high resistance to deactivation) in the DRM process. Ni catalysts supported on Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx MXenes have been synthesized, characterized, and their performance evaluated in DRM. The MXene-based catalysts are benchmarked with traditional catalysts (Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, Ni/SiO2). The study illuminates the role of MXene support properties in catalyst reducibility, catalytic activity, product selectivity, coking resistance, and stability. The effect of catalyst pre-reduction temperature and its interplay with catalytic activity and coking rate is investigated. Additionally, the study utilizes molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to probe oxygen spillover on the MXenes at dry reforming temperature and pressure. Time-resolved mechanistic insights into atomic-scale oxygen dynamics were derived using machine learning-based force fields trained on high-fidelity ab initio data at quantum mechanical-level precision. The results provide insight into the interactions between Ni and MXenes, including a 4d transition metal (Nb) MXene, which will fill a knowledge gap in the field. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis To etch the MAX phase, 1.94 g of Ti3AlC2 (Carbon-Ukraine Ltd) was added to a solution composed of 5.704 g of NH4HF2 (Sigma Aldrich) and 50 ml of distilled water in a round bottom flask. The resulting solution was stirred at 60 °C and 300 rpm for 8 h. The etched MAX phase was vacuum filtered and rinsed several times with ethanol. It was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight to give Ti3C2Tx. A similar technique was used for Nb MXene etching. 5 g of NH4HF2 was added to 50 ml of distilled water in a round bottom flask. 2 g of Nb2AlC (Sigma Aldrich) was added to the solution. This was stirred at 65 °C and 500 rpm for 72 h. Longer time and a slightly higher temperature were used because the Nb-Al bond is stronger than the Ti-Al bond and requires more energy to break [56,57]. The etched MAX phase was then vacuum filtered, rinsed with ethanol, and vacuum dried at 60 °C overnight to give Nb2CTx. The introduction of Ni catalyst to the etched MXenes was carried out by incipient wetness technique. 495 mg of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Alfa Aesar) was dispersed in 20 ml distilled water. 1 g of MXene was added to the solution and sonicated for 30 min. The solution was then vacuum-dried at 60 °C overnight. The Ni/MXene catalysts were annealed in argon at 400 °C for 2 h and then ground and sieved through 100 mesh (Fig. S1). Traditional catalysts (Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, Ni/SiO2) used for benchmarking were also prepared by incipient wetness technique and calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), N2 physisorption, and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). SEM and EDS data were acquired using a Zeiss-Gemini500 Scanning Electron Microscope (Carl Zeiss NTS Ltd., Cambridge, UK) with magnification up to ×200,000. Before imaging, 5 nm iridium was deposited on the sample to avoid charging. TEM was conducted using an electron microscope FEI Tecnai Osiris S/TEM (Fei Co., USA) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Powder XRD was performed using a PANalytical Empyrean Series 2 X-ray diffractometer (Cu k-, 8.04 keV, 0.15406 nm) at a scan speed of 2°/min and accelerating voltage and current of 45 kV and 40 mA, respectively. XPS was performed using the Thermo Scientific K-alpha XPS system (Al kα X-ray source) at a pass energy (PE) of 50 eV and 0.1 eV step size. Peak fitting was performed using a Shirley background and GL30 peaks (30 % Gaussian and 70 % Lorentzian). N2 physisorption was performed using Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ2 (Quantachrome Instruments) using ultra-high-purity N2 (99.999 % purity) at 77 K. The samples were degassed at 200 °C for 600 min. Raman spectroscopy was performed using an Invia Reflex Renishaw microspectrometer equipped with an argon laser (λ0 = 532 nm, source power 20 mW), obtained at 2 s exposure time, 10 % laser power, and 3 accumulations. The wt% of Ni in the catalyst was determined using ICP-MS (NexION 350X, Perkin Elmer). H2-TPR was performed using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation) using ∼ 30 mg sample, 10 % H2-Ar, with a flowrate of 30 mL/min, and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Before measurement, the samples were heated to 150 °C for 1 h in Ar to remove impurities. The spent catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, XPS, Raman spectroscopy, O2-temperature programmed oxidation (O2-TPO), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The description of the methods for the characterization of the spent catalyst is in the Supplementary section M1. 2.3 Catalyst testing DRM was performed in a stainless-steel reactor with ID 1.02 cm, OD 1.27 cm, and length 23.2 cm. The catalyst bed consisted of 1800 mg SiC and 200 mg of MXene catalyst supported at the base and top by quartz wool. The catalyst bed was heated from ambient temperature to the reduction temperature (500 or 700 °C) under N2 flow and was then reduced at the temperature using 210 sccm pure H2 for 30 min. After reduction, methane and carbon dioxide (150 sccm each) were introduced at atmospheric pressure, 700 °C, and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 90,000 ml/gcat h. A K-type thermocouple connected to a thermostat was inserted into the catalyst bed to monitor and control the temperature. A drierite moisture trap was used to remove in situ-generated water from the product stream. After allowing the DRM reaction to equilibrate for 30 min, the product concentration was analyzed using an in-line gas chromatograph GC-TCD (SRI8610C SRI Instruments) equipped with 0.52 mm ID 60MXT1 capillary column, 6′ MS13X molecular sieve packed column, and 6′ silica gel packed column. After DRM, the reactor was cooled to ambient temperature under N2 flow. The quantitative metrics for evaluating the system were determined using Eqs. (1)–(7): (1) H 2 / C O r a t i o = H 2 out C O out (2) - r CH 4 e x p e r i m e n t a l ′ m m o l g Ni - 1 min - 1 = F CH 4 in ml min × X CH 4 W Ni × 1 m m o l 22.4 m l (3) - r CO 2 e x p e r i m e n t a l ′ m m o l g Ni - 1 min - 1 = F CO 2 in ml min × X CO 2 W Ni × 1 m m o l 22 . 4 m l (4) TOF i s - 1 = r i ′ W × ( D / M Ni ) (5) T o t a l s y n g a s p r o d u c t i o n m o l % = y H 2 + y CO × 100 % (6) C o k i n g r a t e μ g C g cat - 1 min - 1 = W coke W cat × T O S (7) N o r m a l i z e d c o k i n g r a t e μ g C mmol C H 4 - 1 = Coking rate Reaction rate μ g C g cat - 1 min - 1 mmol C H 4 g cat - 1 min - 1 where F i in is the inlet flowrate of component i, X i is fractional conversion, r i ′ is the reaction rate in mol/gcat.s, W is Ni fractional loading, D is dispersion, M Ni is the relative atomic mass of Ni (g/mol), y i is the mole fraction of component i in the product stream (obtained from the GC-TCD data), W coke is the mass of coke oxidized from TGA analysis, W cat is the mass of catalysts used for TGA analysis (90 % SiC in the catalyst is accounted for), TOS is the time on stream for the catalyst. 2.4 MD simulations High-accuracy molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were conducted to investigate oxygen spillover on NbC(1 1 1) and TiC(1 1 1) surfaces at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure. Standard slab models for NbC and TiC were obtained from the Materials Project database [58], with mp-910 and mp-631 used for NbC and TiC, respectively. Simulations were performed under isothermal–isobaric conditions using a constant number of particles ensemble, with temperature and pressure regulated via the Berendsen algorithm. The Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) toolkit [59] was employed to set up and execute the simulations. Accurate interatomic forces, commonly referred to as force fields, are essential for MD simulations, as they enable the numerical integration of the equations of motion to track the trajectories of atoms over time. At the outset, suitable force fields for NbC and TiC were not available under the specific conditions of this study. To address this gap, the Matlantis framework (Preferred Computational Chemistry, Inc., Japan) [60] was utilized. Trained on extensive density functional theory (DFT) datasets, Matlantis delivers near-DFT interatomic forces accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency comparable to classical MD. This high-fidelity approach is particularly advantageous for capturing complex phenomena, such as multi-body interactions, bond formation and dissociation, and surface processes, which simpler empirical potentials cannot adequately describe. In MD simulations, the atomic system evolves by iteratively updating positions and velocities based on interatomic forces obtained from the selected force field. Initial conditions, including atomic positions and velocities, are assigned, and the system evolves in discrete time steps. This method provides time-resolved insights into atomic-scale phenomena, including diffusion, adsorption, and other dynamic processes. Integrating machine learning (ML) potentials trained on high-fidelity ab initio data, such as those provided by Matlantis, enhances the accuracy of MD simulations. These ML-based force fields enable quantum mechanical-level precision without the computational expense of pure DFT, making them particularly suited for large-scale systems. For this study, the ML-based force field from Matlantis was employed to model NbC and TiC surfaces at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure. The slab geometries were initially relaxed, with the bottom atomic layers fixed to mimic experimental constraints. Oxygen atoms were randomly distributed on the surface, followed by a subsequent relaxation step to ensure stable initial configurations. Simulations were conducted over 200,000 MD steps with a 1 fs time step, corresponding to a total simulation time of hundreds of picoseconds. Trajectories recorded during the simulations tracked the velocities of oxygen atoms, providing detailed insights into spillover mechanisms. This approach enabled the identification of oxygen migration pathways, adsorption events, and surface rearrangement processes. By leveraging ML-enhanced force fields and detailed MD simulations, the study offers a powerful framework for investigating complex surface phenomena with accuracy and computational efficiency previously unattainable for large-scale systems. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 MXene characterization The SEM micrograph of Ti3AlC2 (Fig. 1 a) shows a tightly stacked morphology typical of MAX phases [29]. After etching with NH4HF2 at 60 °C for 8 h, the presence of gaps within the layers can be observed in the Ti3C2Tx MXene due to the removal of the aluminum layer (Fig. 1b). EDS analysis revealed a 62 % Al reduction after etching. Nb2AlC also showed the typical tightly stacked morphology of MAX phases (Fig. 1c). On the other hand, after etching Nb2AlC at 65 °C for 18 h, there were no observed gaps between the layers (Fig. 1d), even though a 27 % Al reduction was observed. Extending the etching time to 72 h led to the formation of gaps in the MXene (Fig. 1e) and a 46 % Al reduction. Although NH4HF2 is not as aggressive as HF or LiF/HCl in etching Al, it is significantly safer to handle. The EDS data verify that NH4HF2 can etch Nb2AlC. The resulting interlayer in the etched Nb2AlC is useful for Ni catalyst intercalation, as its expansion provides more volume for the catalyst. Usually, the shift of the 002 peak in the XRD pattern towards lower angles is evidence of the successful etching of MXenes [61]. As observed in Fig. 2 a, the 002 peak for Ti3AlC2 shifted from 9.54° to 7.09° after NH4HF2 etching at 60 °C for 8 h. This corresponds to an interlayer spacing of 1.25 nm from Bragg’s equation. This relatively wide interlayer spacing is achieved because of the intercalation of NH4 + ions, which also helps expand the interlayers [62]. HF- and LiF/HCl-etched Ti3AlC2 typically have interlayer spacings around 1 nm [6]. For Nb2AlC, there is no observed change in the interlayer spacing when etched with NH4HF2 at 65 °C for 18 and 72 h (Fig. 2b); the interlayer spacing with the 002 peak at 12.74° is 0.69 nm. As noted earlier, NH4HF2 is a weaker etchant than HF; thus, the stronger Nb-Al bond than Ti-Al will lead to less etching. The lowered intensity and broadening of the 002 peak after etching Ti3AlC2 and Nb2AlC indicate their loss of crystallinity [63]. The etching of the MAX phase is a critical step in the catalyst design process as it provides a larger surface area for catalyst dispersion. For example, the surface area of Ti3AlC2 was originally 8.11 m2/g but increased to 14.78 m2/g after etching (Fig. 3 a–c). However, residual aluminum in the MXene after etching is not a concern because the ones that remain in their MAX phase maintain their stability under DRM conditions. The increased interlayer spacing obtained in Ti3C2Tx indicates a significant proportion of the 10 wt% Ni used for impregnation can infiltrate into the interlayers as opposed to staying on the surface of the MXene. Given the absence of interlayer expansion in Nb2CTx, a smaller amount of catalyst is expected to be sandwiched between the layers. Raman spectroscopic characterization of the MAX phases and MXenes reveals several structural changes in the materials after etching (Fig. 2c). For Ti3AlC2 and Ti3C2Tx, four Raman peaks can be observed (Fig. 2c). ω1 at 150 cm−1 is attributed to the in-plane vibrations of the Ti3C2 layer in the MXene. The increase in the intensity of this peak indicates successful etching of the MXenes layers [64]. ω2 at 241 cm−1 and ω3 at 425 cm−1 are attributed to the in-plane vibrations of surface groups attached to the surface of the MXenes (Ti3C2O(OH) and Ti3C2(OH)2). ω4 at 606 cm−1 is attributed to the in-plane vibrations of Ti3C2(OH)2 and the out-of-plane vibrations of Ti3C2O2 [64]. Similarly, four Raman peaks can also be observed in the spectra of Nb2AlC and Nb2CTx (Fig. 2d). ω1 at 73 cm−1 and ω4 at 659 cm−1 are attributed to the in-plane vibrations of Nb2CO2 [65], whereas ω2 at 128 cm−1 is attributed to the in-plane vibration of Nb2C layer in the MXene [66]. If etching is successful, the Al is replaced by lighter atoms, suppressing the ω2 peak. This is observed in the spectrum for Nb2CTx, which provides complementary verification of the etching of Nb2AlC. ω3 at 246 cm−1 is attributed to the out-of-plane vibrations of Nb2C layer in the MXene [66]. A downshift in ω3 peak suggests an increase in the interlayer spacing, which was not observed for Nb2CTx; this observation is consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 2b). The presence of the D-band (I D) ∼ 1340 cm−1 and G-band (I G) ∼ 1580 cm−1 in the Raman spectra of both MXenes indicate the presence of sp3 and sp2 hybridized carbon [67], which we attribute to the carbon released from the MAX phase due to over-etching [64,68,69]. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The Raman spectra of Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx catalysts (Fig. 2c-d) revealed peaks corresponding to the oxides of titanium and niobium, respectively, suggesting that despite annealing under Ar, some oxidation of the supports occurred. It is also possible that oxidation occurred during the general handling of the catalysts in the air. As shown in the SEM in Fig. 4 a, d, there are distinct changes in the appearance of the MXenes. Specifically, the MXene sheets can be observed in Ni/Ti3C2Tx, with the formation of crystalline structures at the edges, consistent with morphological analysis in other studies and the formation of TiO2 from MXene oxidation [70–72]. The sheets in Ni/Nb2CTx can also be observed along with some spheroidal features. Although the sheets are apparent in Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx, the observed morphological changes are attributed to thermal annealing. TEM micrographs show 18.9 ± 3.5 nm sized Ni particles on Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 4b-c) and 22.4 ± 7.2 nm sized Ni on Nb2CTx (Fig. 4e-f). The high-resolution XPS Ti 2p3/2 spectrum of Ni/Ti3C2Tx shows a prominent peak for Ti bonded to carbon at 456 eV [25], which makes up the MXene layer (Fig. 5 a). The peak for Ti-O at 461 eV is due to partial oxidation of the MXene and oxygen-containing surface terminations. A small peak for Ti2+ at 458 eV was also present, which is typical in Ti 2p deconvolution for Ti3C2Tx [72,73]. For the high-resolution XPS Nb 3d5/2 spectrum of the Ni/Nb2CTx, the peaks ascribed to Nb-C (201 eV) of the MXene sheet and Nb-O from the partial oxidation (207 eV) [74,75] are present (Fig. 5b). The degree of oxidation was quantified using the ratio of the peak area for the metal oxide to the total area of all peak components ( M e O x i d e M e T o t a l ) for the transition metal in the MXene (Table. S2). The degree of oxidation was 0.29 and 0.31 for Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx, respectively. This suggests that under similar processing conditions, their degree of oxidation is essentially the same. Raman spectra of the Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx catalysts also verify the partial oxidation of the MXene supports after annealing, as their oxide peaks are observed. The transition metal carbide peak is dominant in the XPS spectra for both Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx, which is consistent with observations in the literature [25,76]. The Ni 2p3/2 spectra for both Ni/MXene catalysts show the Ni-O peak at 856 eV [77] (Fig. 5c-d). At + 2 eV from the Ni-O peak, the interaction peak of Ni-MXene can be observed. The larger area of this interaction peak for Ni/Nb2CTx compared to Ni/Ti3C2Tx suggests that more Ni is interacting with the support in the former. The ratio of the peak area of NiO-MXene interaction to bulk NiO was determined (Table S2) and observed to be 0.62 and 0.38 for Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx, respectively. The reduction behavior of Ni/MXene catalysts was evaluated and compared to traditional DRM catalysts using TPR; the profiles are presented in Fig. 5e. For Ni/Nb2CTx, the first reduction peak consists of two components, leading to peaks at 346 and 395 °C. This is due to the reduction of bulk NiO. The third peak at 492 °C could be due to the reduction of the Nb2CTx surface via the removal of terminations. For Ni/Ti3C2Tx, the first asymmetric peak at 492 °C is due to the reduction of bulk NiO. The asymmetry suggests the peak has two components, which is reasonable as bulk NiO follows a two-step reduction process from Ni2+ to Ni1+ and then to Ni0. The next peak at 630 °C is due to other nickel oxide species, such as Ni2O3 and Ni(OH)2 on the Ti3C2Tx surface [25]. For Ni/SiO2, the bulk NiO reduction peaks are at 240 and 275 °C, while for Ni/γ-Al2O3, the peaks are at 320 and 445 °C. The H2 consumption of Ni/Nb2CTx (10.4 mmolH2/gcat) is the highest for all catalysts (Table 1 ), indicating a greater reducibility than the other catalysts. This observation is corroborated by the amount (wt.%) of Ni reduced at H2-TPR conditions compared to the original Ni in the catalysts. The value is twice as high as for the other catalysts (Ni/Ti3C2Tx, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, and Ni/SiO2). The catalyst sinters if the pre-reduction temperature is significantly higher than the last H2-TPR peak, resulting in a lower surface-to-volume ratio and reduced catalytic activity. Differences in reducibility among catalysts could be a result of the availability of surface Ni. The study reveals that the reducibility (Table 1) of layered Ni/Ti3C2Tx (11 %) is on par with other heterogenous catalysts with bulk oxide support (8–13 %) while that of layered Ni/Nb2CTx (24 %) is superior. This suggests that the intercalation of Ni in the MXenes does not lead to any comparative disadvantage. The NiO(111) XRD peak was used to determine the crystallite size of the Ni (Table S3) after adjusting for size reduction due to oxygen removal [78]. It was observed that the Ni sizes were 11–15 nm for the catalysts, except for Ni/γ-Al2O3, which was ∼ 6 nm. The dispersion determined using the method of Daoura et al. [79] was 6–9 % for the catalysts except for Ni/γ-Al2O3, which was ∼ 18 %. The following section will address the strong dependence of reaction rates on pre-reduction temperature. 3.3 Catalyst performance in DRM The performance of Ni on different supports at 700 °C reaction temperature was evaluated for 20 h using two different pre-reduction conditions (500 and 700 °C) (Fig. 6 a-b). A feedstock ratio of 1:1 was used with no diluents in the feed. In many DRM studies, diluents are included in the feed at a range of 30–80 % [80–83], which can improve the conversion. The diluents lower the reaction rate, reduce coke formation, and promote stable activity for longer times. However, for the technology to be used on an industrial scale, such high diluent conditions would be non-ideal due to low throughput, low syngas yield, mass transfer limitations, separation considerations, and inefficient reactor utilization. Therefore, this study is interested in evaluating the performance using no inert in the feed. When the catalyst was pre-reduced at 500 °C, the average apparent CH4 reaction rate was within the same range: 104 ± 13 mmol/gNi.min for Ni/Nb2CTx and 100 ± 13 mmol/gNi.min for Ni/Ti3C2Tx. This performance is remarkable for a MXene-supported catalyst as it falls within the same range as Ni/γ-Al2O3 at 108 ± 5 mmol/gNi.min. On the other hand, the average apparent CH4 reaction rates for Ni/MgAl2O4 and Ni/SiO2 were lower at 83 ± 2, and 68 ± 6 mmol/gNi.min, respectively. In particular, the turnover frequency (TOF) was highest in Ni/Nb2CTx at 16.7 s−1 (Fig. S6). After pre-reducing at a higher temperature (700 °C), the catalytic activity of Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 improved, as revealed by their increase in the average apparent CH4 reaction rate to 176 ± 4 and 129 ± 3 mmol/gNi.min, respectively. The activity of Ni/Nb2CTx, Ni/Ti3C2Tx, and Ni/SiO2 after pre-reduction at 700 °C dropped to 36 ± 21, 31 ± 9, and 16 ± 6 mmol/gNi.min, respectively, suggesting that MXene supports are more active when reduced at relatively lower temperatures before DRM. It is known that the surface terminations on the MXene are removed around 500 to 600 °C [51,84,85]. At higher pre-reduction temperatures, we believe the surface of the MXenes is reduced, and the resulting metallic MXene surface has poor MSI with Ni. This leads to rapid sintering of Ni, hence the reduced activity. When the MXene catalytic activity was normalized with the coking rate (Fig. 6c), it was observed that the coking rate of Ni/Nb2CTx, and Ni/SiO2 per CH4 reaction rate is relatively low when pre-reduced at 500 °C. We emphasize that, unlike Ni/SiO2 with a low overall reaction rate, Ni/Nb2CTx is characterized by a high overall reaction rate and a low coking rate—qualities that make Ni/Nb2CTx a promising DRM catalyst. The overall reaction rate is typically the methane reaction rate, as it represents the slowest step in DRM, specifically methane dissociative chemisorption [86]. The average apparent CO2 reaction rate varied significantly for all the catalyst supports (Fig. 6d-e). It increased by a factor of about 1.5 as the pre-reduction temperature increased from 500 °C to 700 °C for all catalysts except Ni/SiO2. The pre-reduction temperature has a bigger influence on the CH4 reaction rate than the CO2 reaction rate because it controls the availability of transition metal sites where the CH4 reactant species are activated. Changes to the CO2 reaction rate are indirect and are more dependent on the coupled nature of the DRM reaction as RWGS also contributes to the rate. However, the reaction quotient for RWGS (0.05 – 0.6) was also lower than that of DRM (1.8 × 105 – 2.9 × 105) for the MXene-supported pre-reduced at 500 °C (Method M3 in SI). Additionally, the CO2 reaction primarily occurs on the support, where support properties, such as morphology, surface area, and oxygen vacancy concentration, evolve over time, varying significantly across different supports and influencing the reaction kinetics. Considering that Ni/Nb2CTx pre-reduced at 500 °C had a low normalized coking rate and high reaction rate, it was quite interesting that the apparent CO2 reaction rate was 98 ± 39 mmol/gNi.min which is around the same level for CH4. This suggests that the efficiency of coke oxidation was not due to a relative abundance of oxygen since the CO2 reaction rate was similar to the CH4 reaction rate, but to more efficient utilization of the available oxygen from CO2 dissociation compared to other catalysts. We propose this hypothesis because it is already well-established in the literature that high CO2 dissociation leads to increased oxygen in the support, which, in turn, results in better coke oxidation [87]. The syngas quality in terms of H2/CO ratio was between 0.5 and 0.7 for all catalysts when pre-reduced at 500 °C (Fig. 6f). Only Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 were able to maintain their syngas quality after pre-reduction at 700 °C, as the ratio dropped for the other catalysts (Fig. 6g). This is consistent with the lowering of the CH4 rate of these catalysts after 700 °C pre-reduction, which leads to lesser hydrogen production. When pre-reduced at 500 °C (Fig. 6h) and 700 °C (Fig. 6i), the total syngas production follows a similar trend. All catalysts exhibit syngas production rates after pre-reduction at 500 °C that are within the same range; Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4 show increased production rates when pre-reduced at 700 °C while there was a decrease for Ni/Ti3C2Tx, Ni/Nb2CTx, and Ni/SiO2. 3.4 MD simulations The dissociated oxygen from CO2 in DRM ultimately forms either water through the RWGS pathway or CO via coke oxidation. While intermediate species such as hydroxyl and formate may transiently exist, they eventually convert to water or CO. The rapid dynamics of hydrogen spillover [88] and the ability of gas-phase hydrogen to reduce surface-adsorbed oxygen [89,90] facilitate the efficient incorporation of dissociated oxygen into the RWGS reaction to produce water. However, since deposited coke predominantly localizes on the catalyst support and carbon oxidation kinetics are relatively slow [91,92], the removal of coke via oxidation depends heavily on oxygen spillover (Fig. 7 a). The efficiency of carbon oxidation is thus directly linked to the extent of oxygen spillover on the support. MD simulations were performed on NbC(111) and TiC(111) surfaces at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure to investigate this phenomenon. The average oxygen velocity was slightly higher on NbC (0.0969 Å/fs) than on TiC (0.0961 Å/fs), as shown in Fig. S7a-b. Over equivalent time scales, the total oxygen spillover distance was calculated as 1.937 µm for NbC and 1.922 µm for TiC (Fig. 7b), corresponding to a difference of 15 nm over a 200 ps period. The simulations reveal significant differences in oxygen mobility between the two materials. The observed difference is attributed to the stronger interaction between oxygen and Ti compared to oxygen and Nb, which influences the mobility of oxygen across the surface. Ti, a 3d transition metal, has a narrower d-band and a lower Fermi level than Nb, a 4d transition metal. The wider d-band in Nb results in less localized electrons, reducing the strength of interaction with surface oxygen. The partially filled d-band in both transition metals facilitates the electron exchange required for oxygen chemisorption, reduction, and spillover [93], but the electronic configuration of Nb enhances oxygen mobility. The simulation results confirm that oxygen atoms exhibit slightly higher mobility on NbC surfaces compared to TiC, highlighting materials-dependent surface interaction properties under identical temperature and pressure conditions. Furthermore, Fig. 7c indicates that oxygen migration was restricted to the surface of the carbides, with no evidence of subsurface diffusion under the given conditions. These results suggest that the low normalized coking rate observed in the Ni/Nb2CTx catalyst can be attributed to the rapid oxygen spillover on NbC, which facilitates efficient coke oxidation. In contrast, the Ti3CTx catalyst exhibits relatively slower oxygen spillover, limiting its effectiveness in coke removal. 3.5 Catalyst structural changes, coking, and sintering For the MXene-supported catalysts, XRD, TGA, Raman spectroscopy, O2-TPO, and XPS were used to study the changes in the catalyst and support after DRM. XRD was used to probe phase transformations and glean insight into the reaction mechanism. Similar phase and compositional changes were observed in Ni/Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 8 a), and Ni/Nb2CTx (Fig. 8b). Before DRM, it is apparent that some partial oxidation of the supports occurred due to catalyst preparation and handling as peaks for the oxide of titanium and niobium could be observed alongside the traditional MXene peaks (see peak labels). After DRM, MXene peaks disappeared, suggesting the destruction of the layered structure of the support. Also, the appearance of additional phases of the oxide and the formation of carbides were observed. It has previously been shown that vanadium- [52] and molybdenum-based [51] MXenes do not retain their layered structure but form stable oxycarbides under DRM conditions. We find a similarity between the observations in these studies and our MXene-supported Ni catalysts. For Ni/Ti3C2Tx, peaks for TiC and TiO2 can be observed, while NbC and Nb2O5 peaks are present for Ni/Nb2CTx. The oxycarbide phase is shown to favor CO2 chemisorption and dissociation [51]. This leads to surface oxygen coverage that limits coking. As shown in the previous section, the carbide phase also favors rapid oxygen spillover. Considering these properties of the oxycarbide phase, it corroborates the low normalized coking rate observed for the Ni/MXene catalysts. The NiC peak is present in the spent MXene-supported catalysts, indicating that the catalytic mechanism involves carbon dissolution into the catalyst and subsequent precipitation as graphitic structures. The coke formation can also be deduced from the XRD patterns. By comparing the graphitic carbon peak at 26.6° with the SiC reference (which makes up 90 % of the spent sample), it can be observed that this peak is more intense for Ni/Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 8a) compared to Ni/Nb2CTx (Fig. 8b). O2-TPO analysis also corroborates this observation (Fig. S8a-e). For the traditional catalysts, a similar trend persists where a low graphitic carbon peak is observed in the XRD patterns for Ni/SiO2 compared to Ni on aluminum-based supports (Fig. S9a-c). The spent catalyst was characterized with TGA and Raman spectroscopy to glean information about the nature and rate of coking. The observed weight loss during TGA can be correlated with coke oxidation in air. For samples with a high amount of coke, the weight loss was steeper (Fig. 9 a-b). The coking rates obtained from the TGA profiles are summarized in Table S4. It can be observed that using 500 and 700 °C pre-reduction temperatures, the coking rate of Ni/Nb2CTx was lower than the rates observed in the other catalysts, except for Ni/SiO2. However, as observed in the performance data, the reaction rate of CH4 for Ni/SiO2 is lower than that of Ni/Nb2CTx. The ratio of oxidized coke at high temperatures compared to coke at low temperatures can be used to differentiate between amorphous (soft) and graphitic (hard) coke. Amorphous carbon is oxidized at lower temperatures, while graphitic coke typically oxidizes at temperatures greater than 500 °C. Aluminum-based supported catalysts (Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4) were observed to have a higher proportion of hard coke, while Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/SiO2 had lower amounts; the amount on Ni/Nb2CTx was intermediate. The I G band is the Raman band for sp2 hybridized carbon, while I D is the band for sp3 hybridized carbon [94,95]; thus, the ratio of the two bands (I G/I D) indicates the quality of the coke produced from the reaction. The Raman spectra showed low I G/I D ratios (< 1) for the aluminum-based supports compared to MXenes and SiO2 (Fig. 9c-d). To further probe the nature of the coke formed by Ni/Ti3C2Tx and Ni/Nb2CTx, high-resolution XPS spectra for the spent catalyst were obtained and compared to fresh catalysts (Fig. 10 a-f). The analysis was also conducted for the traditional catalysts (Fig. S10). For the fresh catalyst, small peaks for adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV (C–C, C–H) and C-OH, C-OC at +1.5 eV above the C–C peak are present. The peak for carbon in titanium carbide is 1.5–3 eV below the C–C peak at 284.8 eV [96,97] (Fig. 10a) while that of carbon in niobium carbide is 2 eV below the C–C peak at 284.8 eV [98,99] (Fig. 10d). These carbidic peaks (for titanium and niobium) originate from the carbon layer in the MXenes and remain in the oxycarbide after the reaction is terminated. The C-Si peak is an artifact from the silicon carbide used to prepare the catalyst bed, which remains in the spent catalyst. The degree of functionalization, characterized by the shoulder in the high binding energy region, usually composed of C-OH, C-OC, C=O, and O-C=O, can be used to evaluate the coking oxidation efficiency during DRM. This oxidized carbon peak shoulder is lower in Ni/Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 10b-c) compared to Ni/Nb2CTx (Fig. 10e-f). This also suggests that coke was more strongly oxidized using Ni/Nb2CTx support compared to Ni/Ti3C2Tx. Peaks for carbon in nickel carbide can also be observed for the MXenes, which corroborates the observation from XRD. The analysis in this section provides further evidence that Ni/Nb2CTx is a promising DRM catalyst due to its low coking rate after pre-reduction at 500 °C. Both MXene supports transitioned to stable oxycarbides during DRM, facilitating a stable performance over extended TOS. This study also examined the sintering resistance of the Ni/MXene catalysts and compared them with Ni/SiO2 (Fig. 11 ). The size distribution was obtained from TEM micrographs of the spent catalyst (Fig. S12-S13) and compared with the fresh catalysts. It was observed that after the reaction at 700 °C and 20 h, Ni size in Ni/Ti3C2Tx increased from 18.9 ± 3.5 to 26.9 ± 6.9 nm (42 % increase). For Ni/Nb2CTx, Ni size increased from 22.4 ± 7.2 to 26.6 ± 7.4 nm (19 % increase). For Ni/SiO2, it was from 29.1 ± 5.9 to 43.2 ± 11.6 nm (48 % increase). This shows that Ni/MXene catalysts have superior sintering resistance compared to Ni/SiO2 at the reaction conditions. Furthermore, Ni/Nb2CTx shows high sintering resistance, which complements its impressive coking resistance. 3.6 Catalyst stability Based on the results discussed so far, Ni/Nb2CTx shows better reaction rates than Ni/Ti3C2Tx and superior coking resistance to the other catalysts studied, except for Ni/SiO2. Our discussion on stability focuses on Ni/Nb2CTx as the coke resistance of Ni/SiO2 has already been reported in the literature [100–102]. To further probe the stability of Ni/Nb2CTx, DRM was conducted at 700 °C for 50 h TOS with no diluents in the feed using 1 wt% Ni pre-reduced at 500 °C (Fig. 12 a). As shown in the data, the reaction rate was stable for 50 h. The CH4 reaction rate (representing the overall reaction rate) was above the average for 28 h, then dropped by approximately 40 % and remained active under similar conditions until it was terminated at 50 h. This further underlines the potential of the catalyst for scalable applications. The normalized coking rate was compared with others reported in the literature (Table S5). It can be observed that MXene supports compare favorably with many other supports. The results from the current investigation show that Ni/Nb2CTx pre-reduced at 500 °C compares favorably in terms of the reaction rates and normalized coking rate to the other catalysts studied in this investigation (Fig. 12b). 4 Conclusions In this study, Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx were evaluated as Ni supports for DRM. It was easier for NH4HF2 to etch Ti3AlC2 compared to Nb2AlC due to the stronger bonds with the aluminum layer in the latter. Ni catalyst supported on Nb2CTx was more easily reduced compared to Ti3C2Tx and the other traditional catalysts under similar conditions. Nb2CTx-supported catalysts had the highest reducibility, and Ni/Nb2CTx pre-reduced at 500 °C exhibited a low normalized coking rate and high overall reaction rate compared to other catalysts. The apparent CO2 reaction rate after pre-reduction of Ni/Nb2CTx at 500 °C was similar to that of CH4, suggesting that the efficient utilization of dissociated oxygen from CO2 could be the reason for the low normalized coking rate. To rationalize this observation, MD simulations with atomic interactions revealed rapid oxygen spillover in the carbides under DRM conditions. Over equivalent time scales (200 ps), the difference in total oxygen spillover between NbC and TiC was 15 nm. Ni/Nb2CTx coking rate for DRM after pre-reduction at 500 °C was quite low at 39 µg/gcat.min and was lower than all other catalysts except Ni/SiO2. Both Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx transitioned to stable oxycarbides during DRM, which are known to be stable supports for the reaction. Ni/Nb2CTx also exhibited superior sintering resistance to Ti3C2Tx. Comparison with prior DRM studies in the literature revealed that the coking rate of Ni/Nb2CTx is relatively lower than other reported catalysts at 700 °C reaction temperature. This study has revealed that MXene support offers superior coking resistance in DRM compared to other traditional catalysts. The oxycarbide formed also allows for stable performance for 50 h TOS, which is comparable to many catalysts in the literature. Unlike MXene support, traditional carbon nanomaterials like carbon nanotubes get oxidized during DRM due to the high reaction temperatures and presence of an oxidant (CO2). This study has provided insights into the coke-limiting ability of Nb2CTx as Ni support in DRM, a breakthrough that is needed for the eventual scale-up of the technology. coredata.dc:description: The development of coke-resistant catalysts for dry reforming of methane (DRM) is critical for sustainable syngas production. To suppress coking, this study investigates the use of Ti3C2Tx and Nb2CTx MXenes as support for Ni catalysts in DRM and benchmarked their performance with conventional catalysts (Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/MgAl2O4, and Ni/SiO2). The MXenes were etched using NH4HF2, and a 10 wt% Ni loading on the supports was achieved via wet impregnation synthesis. Ni/Nb2CTx showed the highest H2 consumption (10.4 mmolH2/gcat). DRM was conducted at 700 °C using a feed ratio of CH4/CO2 of 1:1 and a high space velocity (90,000 ml/gcat h). Unlike the other catalysts, Ni/Nb2CTx pre-reduced at 500 °C exhibited a low normalized coking rate (4.41 µgcoke/mmolCH4), a high overall reaction rate (104 ± 13 mmol/gNi.min), and the highest turnover frequency at 16.7 s−1. The apparent CO2 reaction rate at these conditions was similar to the CH4 rate, suggesting that the low coking rate was due to the efficient utilization of dissociated oxygen. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations performed on NbC(111) and TiC(111) surfaces at 700 °C and atmospheric pressure reveal that the efficient utilization was mediated by rapid oxygen spillover. The average oxygen velocity from the simulations was slightly higher on NbC (0.0969 Å/fs) than on TiC (0.0961 Å/fs). Both MXene supports are transformed to stable oxycarbides during DRM, and Nb2CTx was stable for 50 h TOS. This investigation not only highlights the potential of Ni/Nb2CTx as a coke- and sintering-resistant catalyst but also demonstrates the role of MXenes supports in the DRM process.
